# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session

# How to create a simple numpy array

n_arr = np.array([1,2,3,4,5])
print(n_arr)
print(type(n_arr))
source.8c735524:
# How to create a 2d Numpy array

np_arr_2d = np.array([[1,2,3],[5,6,7]])
print(np_arr_2d)
print(type(np_arr_2d))
source.9fbd10c0:
# How to create Numpy Array with all zeros

np_zeros = np.zeros((3,2))
# This will create 3 rows and 2 cols numpy array
print(np_zeros)
source.3d7870e3:
# How to create numpy array with a custom number

np.full((3,2), fill_value=5)
source.f43e003e:
# how to create numpy array with in a range

np.arange(1,10)
source.cfaea53b:
# how to create numpy array with in a range but with a gap

# below result will be with a gap of 2
np.arange(1,10,2)
source.bcda7e06:
# Numpy array with 5 values in the range of 1 to 10

np.random.randint(1,10,5)
source.0767ff36:
# create a random 3 by 3 Numpy Multideimensgional Array with lists

my_arr = np.array([list(np.random.randint(1,10,3)), list(np.random.randint(1,10,3))])
my_arr
source.8014132e:
# Find the shape of Numpy array

# result will be 2 rows and 3 cols
my_arr.shape
source.cec0fa77:
# Joining functions in Numpy 

arr_1 = np.random.randint(1,10,4)
print("Array 1 : ", arr_1)
arr_2 = np.random.randint(1,10,4)
print("Array 2 : ", arr_2)
# Lets concat
np.concatenate((arr_1, arr_2))
source.c5e9c6cb:
# Joining functions in Numpy - 2D Array - Add row vise

arr1 = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]])
arr2 = np.array([[5, 6], [7, 8]])
arr = np.concatenate((arr1, arr2), axis=0)

print(arr)
source.cf8515fd:
# Joining functions in Numpy - 2D Array - Add col vise

arr1 = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]])
arr2 = np.array([[5, 6], [7, 8]])
arr = np.concatenate((arr1, arr2), axis=1)

print(arr)
source.bb157021:
# vstack joining - same as adding row vise

np.vstack((arr1, arr2))
source.7bfd0fed:
# hstack joining - same as adding col vise

np.hstack((arr1, arr2))
source.d60bb304:
# dstack joining 

my_arr = np.column_stack((arr1, arr2))
my_arr
source.92ed1df6:
# Reshape function
print(my_arr.shape)
my_arr.shape = (4,2)
# Now it will be 4 rows and 2 cols.
my_arr
source.cc531cc6:
# Set Functions like union and intersaction and difference A-B and B-A

#1. Union

arr_1 = np.array([1,4,5,6,7,8])
print(arr_1)
arr_2 = np.array([3,4,8,9,10])
print(arr_2)

print("Union Result")
print(np.union1d(arr_1, arr_2))

print("Intersaction Result")
print(np.intersect1d(arr_1, arr_2))

print("A-B")
print(np.setdiff1d(arr_1, arr_2))

print("B-A")
print(np.setdiff1d(arr_2, arr_1))
